ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic grant writing and grant presentation skills.
Looked at biotechnology and healthcare from a completely different angle! With different considerations and cultural perspectives!
project design, critical thinking, human-centered design, grant writing
Learned a lot!
This class taught us how to take a deeper look and think more about implementing technology and its corresponding context.
Knowledge on Gates Global Grand Challenge

* Overview of global health & disease burden in the developing world + metrics used to assess such
* Broad overview of biotechnology's role in global health
* Understand the policy influence / stakeholder role in adopting biotech to overcome global health crisis
* Review factors driving vaccine hesitancy
* How to navigate Yale library resources
* Asks you to consider cultural, ethical q's of biotech

Ultimately, this class helps to provide direction for funding and a framework for how to develop, test, and validate novel biotechnologies.
I learned about the correct ways to think through innovations that will be beneficial to the community you are targeting

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very collaborative course.

Strengths: fascinating material and projects / proposals were the best part!
Weaknesses: none
Very informative and fun class. Some of the students seemed very disengaged and that could be distracting during presentations.

Strengths: the project based nature of the course combined with the relevant lecture series was incredible and unlike any other class I've taken at yale. it was so different than your standard lecture where you take notes and regurgitate the information on the test- we instead applied what we learned to two major projects. 

weaknesses: honestly none.
The strength is the open discussion (seminar like) course. Anyone could speak and give their opinion.
Great class, great professor

Strength: Interesting material
Weakness: Wished that the midterm & final projects were more guided by class structure. More checks for feedback and improvements

This class was engaging and the correct amount of work. The projects were interesting but especially for the final project I think there should have been a little more structure to encourage starting with an idea sooner

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes.  Good course for basic grant writing skills.
Great change of pace for a junior/senior BME major who want's a more humanities-centered STEM course.

Yes! This is a FANTASTIC course for anyone going into biotech / healthcare in any capacity. It's just so interesting to look at the cultural perspectives and social implications (public health) of some of the technological advancements in biotech today. The projects are incredibly insightful if you put in the effort as well!
Yes, it allows you to find applications for your own research into the biotech space.

ABSOLUTELY! Everyone even vaguely interested in health, global health, or innovation should take this couse. Even if you're not explicitly interested in start-ups/med tech, it provides so many interesting new frameworks of thinking (human centered design, medical considerations in the developing world). It's also just a fun class, and Prof. Gonzalez is amazing.
Yes!! It is an amazing class and it is also project based that is practical going forward.
Definitely take this!
Yes, important topics if interested in global health / biotech development
Yes! Just make sure to start thinking of your final project early
Yes
